case_vignette: A 34-year-old healthy female presents for evaluation of a bump on her left third finger present over the past nine months. She denies any trauma to the area and first noticed it when getting a manicure. The spot began as a small bump that progressively enlargened with associated depression of the fingernail. Physical examination of the left third finger reveals a translucent nodule along the proximal nail fold with associated longitudinal depression of the nail plate.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a bump on my left third finger that has grown over time and my fingernail on that finger has a dent in it.
Has the bump changed in color or does it cause you any pain?
No, the bump hasn't changed in color and it doesn't cause any pain.
Is there any history of similar issues in your family?
No, there's no history of similar issues in my family.
Have you noticed any changes in the skin texture around the bump, or any fluid discharge from it?
No, there are no changes in the skin texture around the bump and no fluid discharge from it.
Have you had any previous injuries or infections on that finger, or have you been exposed to any chemicals or irritants?
No, I haven't had any injuries or infections on that finger, and I haven't been exposed to any chemicals or irritants.
Final Diagnosis: Subungual Exostosis
